abstract: Inozume et al. describe a novel immunosuppressive mechanism in melanoma that is triggered by the interaction between CD155 (expressed by melanomas) and T-cell Ig and ITIM domain (TIGIT) (expressed by tumor infiltrating lymphocytes). This pathway exists in addition to the "classical" co-inhibitory PD-1-PD-L1 pathway. Hence, the combinatorial blockage of both pathways by specific antibodies resulted in the greatly enhanced effector function of melanoma-specific cytotoxic T cells. Given that CD155-TIGIT signaling exerts potent inhibitory action in different subsets of immune cells and that CD155 is expressed broadly in several tumor entities, this report points toward a novel and promising therapeutic strategy to combine different checkpoint blocking agents for greater success in antitumor therapy.
title: TIGIT-CD155 Interactions in Melanoma: A Novel Co-Inhibitory Pathway with Potential for Clinical Intervention.
